awd_titl_txt: PFI:AIR - TT:  High yield production of furans from biomass hydrolysates using a hybrid enzyme- and chemo-catalytic technology
awd_abstract_narration:
This PFI: AIR Technology Translation project focuses on a transformative technology for converting biomass to platform chemicals (furans) that would replace petroleum-derived feedstocks for fuel and chemical production.  These furans serve as building blocks for a variety of other chemicals and intermediates that are necessary in industry. A process that allows them to be economically produced from renewable resources (e.g. biomass) instead of petroleum-based technologies would result in reduced dependence on fossil fuels, reduced emission of greenhouse gases, and minimal environmental impact. 

The project will result in a proof-of-concept development, demonstration, and evaluation of an integrated hybrid enzyme-and chemo-catalytic technology for high-yield production of furans from biomass sugars. When compared to competing processes that rely on inefficient water-based reaction media, the technology has several distinct advantages. It provides a cohesive pathway to efficiently transfer biomass sugars into a non-aqueous reaction medium; produces the furan product in high yield; and isolates the furan for downstream processing, all with low energy input and recycling of process streams. 

This project addresses the following technology gaps as it translates from research discovery toward commercial application: (1) the design, construction, and testing of a scalable process configuration that allows transition from bench to larger scale; (2) the collection of metrics for the prolonged operation of the integrated process; (3) the assessment of the process economics and environmental impacts; and (4) the evaluation of the integrated process with diverse biomass feedstocks and their upstream pretreatment/saccharification methods. In addition, personnel involved in this project, namely undergraduate and graduate students, will receive entrepreneurship and innovation experiences through new interdisciplinary initiatives developed at The University of Toledo based on the Lean LaunchPad approach.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: RET SUPP-Res Exp for Tchr Supp
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of this project was to develop proof-of-concept for an integrated system to produce furans in high yield from biomass-derived sugars. The method entailed simultaneous-isomerization-and-reactive-extraction (SIRE) of the sugars from an aqueous biomass hydrolysate to an organic extraction phase. The sugars were recovered from the extraction phase by back-extraction (BE) into an organic-immiscible phase and dehydrated to furans. The project was designed to assess the process metrics for the prolonged operation of the integrated process of SIRE followed by BE and dehydration in ionic liquid (IL). We had previously demonstrated the component steps at laboratory scale, and through this project further refined, validated, and improved the efficiency of both hydroxymethyl furfural (HMF) and furfural production.

We used naphthalene-2-boronic acid (N2B) as the sugar complexing agent for reactive extraction of the sugars into the organic phase and established operating curves for sugar extraction efficiency as a function of N2B concentration. We also evaluated the IL for reuse and found no reduction in furan yield after three cycles of recovery and reuse.

To further improve the overall process economics, we evaluated alternatives to IL for the dehydration phase. We can easily back-extract fructose from the organic phase by contacting with acidic water, but furans are not stable in acidic water under the conditions of dehydration. We identified several promising polar aprotic solvents that could be added to the water phase to stabilize the furans produced. The most promising co-solvent was 1,2-dimethoxyethane (DME). An acidic fructose-rich aqueous solution obtained from SIRE-BE was mixed with DME and heated to allow sugar dehydration and formation of HMF. After optimizing reaction parameters in the water-DME system, we report that using HCl as a catalyst (55mM) with a glucose to fructose ratio of 1:4 and a high sugar loading of 25 wt% (on a water-basis), we achieve an HMF yield of 87% at 120 C after 30 min with complete conversion of fructose and marginal conversion of glucose (18%).

Recovery of HMF from the water-DME system is energy-efficient due to the low heat of vaporization of DME (383 kJ/kg, 85 C). Our techno-economic assessment of the process estimates a minimum selling price of HMF isolated using vacuum evaporation of solvents (water and DME) to be $1.22/kg when glucose is sourced at $0.236/kg. We also demonstrate a pathway to recover unreacted glucose and HMF from the product mixture of water-DME by phase splitting using toluene as the ternary solvent. When HMF is recovered in toluene for 2,5-diformylfuran and 2,5-furan dicarboxylic acid applications, the minimum selling price is estimated to be $1.19/kg-HMF (toluene-free basis).

Broader Impacts

A viable biorefinery based on the "furan platform" will have a huge societal, economic and commercial impact in light of the fact that furans are recognized as one of the most versatile building block chemicals that can be made from the renewable feed source of lignocellulosic biomass. Furans can be converted to hydrocarbon molecules compatible with jet and/or diesel fuels and can also be modified to make gasoline-additives. HMF and furfural can also serve as precursors for a number of industrially-important chemical products, synthetic materials, and pharmaceutical molecules. Catalytic oxidation of HMF to 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) has been shown to be an environmentally sustainable alternative to terephthalic acid, the petrochemical precursor for PET plastic, with well over $50 billion market capitalization worldwide.

This project supported the education and training of high school through doctoral level students and a high school teacher; students and participants recruited were supported with REU, RET, and INTERN supplements.

 


Last Modified: 05/13/2024
Modified by: Patricia A Relue
